description:
Bradypodion pumilum, commonly known as the dwarf chameleon or Cape dwarf chameleon, is a small species of chameleon native to the southwestern regions of South Africa. It belongs to the genus Bradypodion, which is a group of small to medium-sized chameleons found in parts of Africa.

The dwarf chameleon is characterized by its diminutive size, typically ranging from 10 to 15 centimeters in length. It has a distinctive casque (a helmet-like structure on the head) and a laterally compressed body, which are typical features of chameleons. The species exhibits a range of color variations, including shades of green, brown, and gray, which it can change to blend in with its environment.

Bradypodion pumilum is an arboreal species, spending most of its time in the vegetation, where it hunts for small insects and other invertebrates. It has specialized feet with zygodactylous toes, allowing it to grasp and move through the branches with ease. The dwarf chameleon is known for its slow, deliberate movements and its ability to swivel its eyes independently, enabling it to scan its surroundings for prey and potential predators.

This species is found in various habitats, including fynbos vegetation, thickets, and urban areas with suitable plant cover. It is considered a relatively common and adaptable species within its limited range in the Western and Eastern Cape provinces of South Africa.
